column1: #Text=Polycrystalline PtTe2 films were synthesized by first depositing a Pt metal layer onto a substrate, and then electrodepositing Te on top of this.
#Text=The substrates were then placed in nested crucibles in a quartz-tube furnace, as shown in the supporting information (SI), Figure S1.
#Text=The nested crucibles served to maintain a high local concentration of Te in the vicinity of the samples, while minimizing the quantitiy of Te required in the furnace.
#Text=The formation of PtTe2 took place under a ~700 mbar N2 atmosphere with a dwell time of 90 minutes.
#Text=The effect of the growth temperature is discussed later in the paper.

#Text=Predeposition of the Pt and Te layers allowed for strong control to be maintained over the reactant quantity on each sample, while also providing intimate contact between the reactants during the reaction.
#Text=An advantage of this method is that the thickness of the final PtTe2 films can be defined by controlling the thickness of the initial precursor layers.
#Text=This method also allows large-area, uniform films with defined patterns to be synthesized, which is challenging for CVD-type processes.
